message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamics on higher-order networks: a review
Paper Abstract: Network science has evolved into an indispensable platform for studying complex systems. But recent research has identified limits of classical networks, where links connect pairs of nodes, to comprehensively describe group interactions. Higher-order networks, where a link can connect more than two nodes, have therefore emerged as a new frontier in network science. Since group interactions are common in social, biological and technological systems, higher-order networks have recently led to important new discoveries across many fields of research. Here, we review these works, focusing in particular on the novel aspects of the dynamics that emerges on higher-order networks. We cover a variety of dynamical processes that have thus far been studied, including different synchronization phenomena, contagion processes, the evolution of cooperation and consensus formation. We also outline open challenges and promising directions for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Network science":

## Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).

## Theoretical Foundations

The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## Historical Development

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies, leading to the term 'network science'. Links: [{"title":"Complex system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system"},{"title":"Complex adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_adaptive_system"},{"title":"Category:Complex systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Complex_systems_theory"},{"title":"Large-scale Complex IT Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large-scale_Complex_IT_Systems"},{"title":"Advances in Complex Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Complex_Systems"},{"title":"New England Complex Systems Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Complex_Systems_Institute"},{"title":"Complex and Adaptive Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_and_Adaptive_Systems_Laboratory"},{"title":"Complex systems biology","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_systems_biology"},{"title":"Complex Systems (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_Systems_(journal)"},{"title":"Complex dynamic systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_dynamic_systems_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of complex systems:

## Definition

A complex system is a system composed of many components that interact with one another.(no content)The term complex systems often refers to the study of complex systems, which is an approach to science that investigates how relationships between a system's parts give rise to its collective behaviors and how the system interacts and forms relationships with its environment.

## Key Characteristics

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.(no content)Complex systems have multiple interacting components whose collective behavior cannot be simply inferred from the behavior of components.

## Examples

Examples of complex systems are Earth's global climate, organisms, the human brain, infrastructure such as power grid, transportation or communication systems, complex software and electronic systems, social and economic organizations (like cities), an ecosystem, a living cell, and, ultimately, for some authors, the entire universe.

## Scientific Approach

The study of complex systems regards collective, or system-wide, behaviors as the fundamental object of study; for this reason, complex systems can be understood as an alternative paradigm to reductionism, which attempts to explain systems in terms of their constituent parts and the individual interactions between them.(no content)Complex systems is therefore often used as a broad term encompassing a research approach to problems in many diverse disciplines, including statistical physics, information theory, nonlinear dynamics, anthropology, computer science, meteorology, sociology, economics, psychology, and biology.

Links: [{"title":"Synchronization of chaos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_of_chaos"},{"title":"Synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization"},{"title":"Synchronization network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_network"},{"title":"Synchronization (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Swarmalators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarmalators"},{"title":"TCP global synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP_global_synchronization"},{"title":"Neural synchrony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_synchrony"},{"title":"Albert C.J. Luo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_C.J._Luo"},{"title":"Synchronous dynamic random-access memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronous_dynamic_random-access_memory"},{"title":"Coupled map lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupled_map_lattice"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **synchronization dynamics**:

## General Definition

Synchronization is the coordination of events to operate a system in unison.(no content)Synchronization is an emergent property that occurs in a broad range of dynamical systems, including neural signaling, the beating of the heart and the synchronization of fire-fly light waves.

## Types of Synchronization in Chaotic Systems

Systems are said to be completely synchronized when there is a set of initial conditions so that the systems eventually evolve identically in time. Several specific types include:

- **Phase Synchronization**: Phase synchronization occurs when the coupled chaotic oscillators keep their phase difference bounded while their amplitudes remain uncorrelated.

- **Generalized Synchronization**: Generalized synchronization occurs when there is a functional relationship such that the dynamical state of one of the oscillators is completely determined by the state of the other.

## Synchronization Networks

A synchronization network is a network of coupled dynamical systems consisting of a network connecting oscillators, where oscillators are nodes that emit a signal with somewhat regular frequency, and are also capable of receiving a signal.(no content)The Kuramoto model in the 1970s and 1980s was developed to describe large systems of coupled oscillators.

## Applications

Synchronization dynamics appear across various fields, from physiological systems spanning from metabolic and genomic scales to cellular and neuronal networks, to organs and the organism level, to network communications and artificial systems.

Luo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_C.J._Luo"},{"title":"Synchronous dynamic random-access memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronous_dynamic_random-access_memory"},{"title":"Coupled map lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupled_map_lattice"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **synchronization dynamics**:

## General Definition

Synchronization is the coordination of events to operate a system in unison.(no content)Synchronization is an emergent property that occurs in a broad range of dynamical systems, including neural signaling, the beating of the heart and the synchronization of fire-fly light waves.

## Types of Synchronization in Chaotic Systems

Systems are said to be completely synchronized when there is a set of initial conditions so that the systems eventually evolve identically in time. Several specific types include:

- **Phase Synchronization**: Phase synchronization occurs when the coupled chaotic oscillators keep their phase difference bounded while their amplitudes remain uncorrelated.

- **Generalized Synchronization**: Generalized synchronization occurs when there is a functional relationship such that the dynamical state of one of the oscillators is completely determined by the state of the other.

## Synchronization Networks

A synchronization network is a network of coupled dynamical systems consisting of a network connecting oscillators, where oscillators are nodes that emit a signal with somewhat regular frequency, and are also capable of receiving a signal.(no content)The Kuramoto model in the 1970s and 1980s was developed to describe large systems of coupled oscillators.

## Applications

Synchronization dynamics appear across various fields, from physiological systems spanning from metabolic and genomic scales to cellular and neuronal networks, to organs and the organism level, to network communications and artificial systems.

Web search results for query: "Contagion process epidemic"

Links: [{"title":"Contagion (2011 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagion_(2011_film)"},{"title":"Hysterical contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hysterical_contagion"},{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Contagious disease - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagious_disease"},{"title":"Crimson Contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimson_Contagion"},{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_in_epidemiology"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Emotional contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_epidemic"},{"title":"Infectious period - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infectious_period"},{"title":"Complex contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_contagion"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about contagion processes in epidemics:

## Definition of Epidemic

An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of hosts in a given population within a short period of time.

## Causes of Epidemics

Epidemics of infectious disease are generally caused by several factors including a change in the ecology of the host population (e.g., increased stress or increase in the density of a vector species), a genetic change in the pathogen reservoir or the introduction of an emerging pathogen to a host population.

## Disease Transmission

A contagious disease is an infectious disease that can be spread rapidly in several ways, including direct contact, indirect contact, and droplet contact.(no content)These diseases are caused by organisms such as parasites, bacteria, fungi, and viruses.

## Infectious Period

The infectious period is the time interval during which a host is infectious, i.e. capable of directly or indirectly transmitting pathogenic infectious agents to another susceptible host.(no content)After pathogens enter a host's body, they usually require time to multiply, and after they become numerous enough, the host becomes able to transmit them into the environment, which marks the beginning of the infectious period.

## Mathematical Modeling

Researchers have proposed nonlinear forces of infection to model more realistically the contagion process.(no content)Epidemiologists and public health officials use these models for analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting infections and recoveries over time, and estimating key epidemiological parameters.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Consensus formation"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reducing consensus to an algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reducing_consensus_to_an_algorithm"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus theory of truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory_of_truth"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about consensus formation:

## Overview

Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community. The term has multiple applications across different fields and contexts.

## Key Areas of Consensus Formation

**Decision-Making**: Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.(no content)Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone) even if some donot fully agree to or support all aspects of it.

**Dynamics in Multi-Agent Systems**: Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory. It studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

**Computer Science**: A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes. This often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

**Scientific Context**: Scientific consensus is the majority judgment and position by active, qualified experts in a specific scientific discipline to establish a conclusion or fact.

## Historical Development

Consensus decision-making, as a self-described practice, originates from several nonviolent, direct action groups that were active in the Civil rights, Peace and Women's movements in the USA during counterculture of the 1960s.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Evolution of cooperation"

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-operation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_Aid:_A_Factor_of_Evolution"},{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Hermann Reinheimer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Reinheimer"},{"title":"European Union Military Operation in the Republic of Macedonia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union_Military_Operation_in_the_Republic_of_Macedonia"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative coevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_coevolution"},{"title":"The Origins of Virtue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Origins_of_Virtue"}]

Here are the search results for "Evolution of cooperation":

## Overview

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)Prominent biologists such as Charles Darwin, E. O. Wilson, and W. D. Hamilton have found the evolution of cooperation fascinating because natural selection favors those who achieve the greatest reproductive success while cooperative behavior often decreases the reproductive success of the actor, posing achallenging problem to the theory of natural selection.

## Key Theories and Mechanisms

There have been multiple hypotheses for the evolution of cooperation, all of which are rooted in Hamilton's models based on inclusive fitness, hypothesizing that cooperation is favored by natural selection due to either direct fitness benefits (mutually beneficial cooperation) or indirect fitness benefits (altruistic cooperation).(no content)Reciprocal altruism was initially developed by Robert Trivers to explain the evolution of cooperation as instances of mutually altruistic acts.(no content)Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behaviour may be favored by the probability of future mutual interactions.

## Influential Works

The Evolution of Cooperation is a 1984 book written by political scientist Robert Axelrod that expands upon a paper of the same name written by Axelrod and evolutionary biologist W.D. Hamilton.(no content)The book details a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals, drawing from game theory and evolutionary biology.(no content)Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution is a 1902 collection of anthropological essays by Russian naturalist Peter Kropotkin that explores the role of mutually beneficial cooperation and reciprocity in the animal kingdom and human societies.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This paper is a literature review that surveys and synthesizes existing research on dynamics on higher-order networks.

**Key Entities Extracted:**

I identified and validated 6 key entities from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Network science** - The foundational field providing theoretical frameworks for studying networks
2. **Complex system** - The core subject representing systems with interacting components and emergent behavior
3. **Synchronization** - A key dynamical process where coupled oscillators coordinate their behavior
4. **Epidemic** - Models contagion and information diffusion processes on networks
5. **Co-operation (evolution)** - Addresses evolution of cooperative behavior in multi-agent systems
6. **Consensus dynamics** - Studies how agents reach agreement through network interactions

All entities have been:
- Linked to their Wikipedia articles
- Classified by type (5 concepts, 1 task)
- Tagged with "uses" relations (appropriate for a survey paper)
- Provided with relevance explanations

The validation script confirmed all entries pass requirements including proper Wikipedia URLs and JSON structure.

Sources:
- [Network science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science)
- [Complex system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system)
- [Synchronization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization)
- [Epidemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic)
- [Co-operation (evolution)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-operation_(evolution))
- [Consensus dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics)
